titleStmt.title: Intuitionistic fuzzy ordered weighted distance operator

analytic.title: Intuitionistic fuzzy ordered weighted distance operator

biblStruct.note: Received 15 October 2010 Received in revised form 24 May 2011 Accepted 25 May 2011

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

textClass.keywords: Intuitionistic fuzzy set Distance measures OWA operator Intuitionistic fuzzy ordered weighted distance Group decision-making

div.p: The ordered weighted distance [27,49] is a new decision-making technique, having been proved useful for the treatment of input data in the form of exact numbers. In this paper, we consider the situation with intuitionistic fuzzy information and develop an intuitionistic fuzzy ordered weighted distance (IFOWD) operator. The IFOWD operator is very suitable to deal with the situations where the input data are represented in intuitionistic fuzzy information and includes a wide range of distance measures and aggregation operators. We study some of its main properties and different families of IFOWD operators. Finally, we develop an application of the new approach in a group decision-making under intuitionistic fuzzy environment and illustrate it with a numerical example.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: The ordered weighted averaging (OWA) operator [55] is a very well-known aggregation operator that provides a parameterized family of aggregation operators that includes the maximum, the minimum, and the average, as special cases. The prominent characteristic of the OWA operator is the reordering step. Since its appearance, the OWA operator has been used in a wide range of applications such as [1,2,5,7,10,15,16,[20][21][22][23][24][25][26][27][28]33,37,39,40,[56][57][58][59][60].

An interesting extension of the OWA is the one that uses distance measures in the OWA operator. Motivated by the idea of the OWA operator, Xu and Chen [49] introduced the ordered weighted distance (OWD) measure, and gave some methods to determine its weights. The prominent characteristic of the OWD measure is that it can relieve (or intensify) the influence of unduly large or unduly small deviations on the aggregation results by assigning them low (or high) weights. This desirable characteristic makes the OWD measure very suitable to be used in many actual fields such as group decision-making, medical diagnosis, data mining, and pattern recognition. The OWD also generalizes a variety of well-known distance measures and aggregation operators, including the normalized Hamming distance, the normalized Euclidean distance, the OWA operator, etc. Yagexr [59] generalized Xu and Chen's distance measures and provided a variety of ordered weighted averaging norms, based on which he proposed several similarity measures. Combining the OWA operator with Hamming distance, Merigó and Gil-Lafuente [27] introduced a new decisionmaking technique called the ordered weighted averaging distance (OWAD) operator. The main advantage of this operator is that we can take into account the attitudinal character of the decisionmaker. Therefore, we are able to provide decision maker with an approach to the optimal choice according to his or her interests. Another advantage of the OWAD operator is that it provides a parameterized family of distance aggregation operators that ranges from the minimum to the maximum distance. Thus, they can provide a wide range of situations depending on the particular attitude taken by the decision maker in the specific problem considered. Moreover, with the OWAD, it is possible to establish an ideal, though unrealistic, alternative in order to compare it with available options in the decision-making problem. As such, the optimal choice is the alternative closest to the ideal one. Going a step further, Merigó and Gil-Lafuente [28] analyzed the use of the OWAD operator in the selection of human resources in sport management. For further research on the use of other different types of distance measures in the OWA operator, see, for example [14,[21][22][23][24][25]52].

Usually, when using the OWD measure and the OWAD operator, it is assumed that the available information is clearly known and can be assessed with exact numbers. However, in the real-life world, due to the increasing complexity of the socioeconomic environment and the lack of knowledge or data about the problem domain, exact numbers are sometimes unavailable. Thus, the input arguments may be vague or fuzzy in nature. Atanassov [3] defined the notion of an intuitionistic fuzzy set (IFS), whose basic elements are intuitionistic fuzzy numbers (IFNs) [40,46,54], each of which is composed of a membership degree and a nonmembership degree. In many practical situations, particularly in the process of group decision making under uncertainty, the experts may come from different research areas and thus have different backgrounds and levels of knowledge, skills, experience, and personality. The experts may not have enough expertise or possess a sufficient level of knowledge to precisely express their preferences over the objects, and then, they usually have some uncertainty in providing their preferences, which makes the results of cognitive performance exhibit the characteristics of affirmation, negation, and hesitation. In such cases, the data or preferences given by the experts may be appropriately expressed in IFNs. For example, in multi-criteria decision-making problems, such as personnel evaluations, medical diagnosis, project investment analysis, etc., each IFN provided by the expert can be used to express both the degree that an alternative should satisfy a criterion and the degree that the alternative should not satisfy the criterion. The IFN is highly useful in depicting uncertainty and vagueness of an object, and thus can be used as a powerful tool to express data information under various different fuzzy environments which has attracted great attentions [36,37,41,44,48,53,54,61]. Therefore, it is necessary to extend the above ordered weighted measures to accommodate the intuitionistic fuzzy situation, which is also the focus of this paper.

For this purpose, we shall develop an intuitionistic fuzzy ordered weighted distance (IFOWD) operator. This operator is very effective for the treatment of the data in the form of IFNs. The main advantage of the IFOWD operator is that it can alleviate the influence of unduly large (or small) deviations on the aggregation results by assigning them low (or high) weights. Moreover, it provides a robust formulation that includes a wide range of particular cases, such as the intuitionistic fuzzy max distance, the intuitionistic fuzzy min distance, the intuitionistic fuzzy normalized Hamming distance (IFNHD), the intuitionistic fuzzy normalized Euclidean distance (IFNED), the intuitionistic fuzzy normalized geometric distance (IFNGD), the intuitionistic fuzzy weighted Hamming distance (IFWHD), the intuitionistic fuzzy weighted Euclidean distance (IFWED), the intuitionistic fuzzy weighted geometric distance (IFWGD), the intuitionistic fuzzy ordered weighted Hamming distance (IFOWHD), the intuitionistic fuzzy ordered weighted Euclidean distance (IFOWED), the intuitionistic fuzzy ordered weighted geometric distance (IFOWGD) and the generalized intuitionistic fuzzy ordered weighted averaging (GIFOWA) operator [62]. Thus, the decision maker is able to consider a wide range of scenarios and select the one that is in accordance with his interests.

This paper is structured as follows. In Section 2, we review some aggregation operators and the ordered weighted distance measures. In Section 3, we develop the IFOWD operator, and study some its various properties. In Section 4, we analyze different types of IFOWD operators. Section 5 briefly describes the decision making process based on developed operators and we give a numerical example in Section 6. Section 7 summarizes the main conclusions of the paper.

div.head: Preliminaries
div.p: In this Section we briefly review some the OWA operator, the ordered weighted averaging distance (OWAD) and ordered weighted distance (OWD) measure.

div.head: The OWA operator
div.p: The ordered weighted averaging (OWA) operator introduced by Yager [55] operator provides a parameterized family of aggregation operators that include the maximum, the minimum and the average criteria. The prominent advantage of the OWA operator is that the input data are rearranged in descending order, and the weights associated with the OWA operator are the weights of the ordered positions of the input data rather than the weights of the input data. It can be defined as follows.
Definition 1. An OWA operator of dimension n is a mapping OWA: R n ? R that has an associated weighting W and P n j¼1 w j ¼ 1 such that:
div.formula: OWAða 1 ; . . . ; a n Þ ¼ X n j¼1 w j b j ;ð1Þ
div.p: where b j is the jth largest of the a i . From a generalized perspective of the reordering step, it is possible to distinguish between the descending OWA (DOWA) operator and the ascending OWA (AOWA) operator. The OWA operator is commutative, monotonic, bounded and idempotent.

div.head: The OWAD operator
div.p: Recently, Merigó and Gil-Lafuente [27] introduced a new index for decision-making using the OWA operator to calculate Hamming distance called the ordered weighted averaging distance (OWAD) operator. For two real numbers sets A = {a 1 , a 2 , . . . , a n } and B = {b 1 , b 2 , . . . , b n }, the OWAD operator can be defined as follows:
Definition 2. An OWAD operator of dimension n is a mapping OWAD: R n Â R n ? R that has an associated weighting W with w j 2 [0, 1] and P n j¼1 w j ¼ 1 such that:
div.formula: OWADðha 1 ; b 1 i; ha 2 ; b 2 i; . . . ; ha n ; b n iÞ ¼ X n j¼1 w j d j ;ð2Þ
div.p: where d j represents the jth largest of the ja i À b i j.
The OWAD operator is commutative, monotonic, bounded and idempotent, it operator provide a parameterized family of aggregation operators ranging from the minimum to the maximum distance.

div.head: The OWD measure
div.p: Motivated by the idea of the OWA operator, Xu and Chen [49] developed an ordered weighted distance (OWD) measure, which can be defined as following: Definition 3. An ordered weighted distance of dimension n is a mapping OWD: R n Â R n ? R that has an associated weighting W with w j 2 [0, 1] and P n j¼1 w j ¼ 1, according to the following formula:
OWDðA; BÞ ¼ X n j¼1 w j ðdða rðjÞ ; b rðjÞ ÞÞ k

where d(a j , b j ) = ja j À b j j is the distance between the real numbers a j and b j , and (r(1), r(2),. . ., r(n)) is any permutation of (1, 2, . . . , n), such that dða rðjÀ1Þ ; b rðjÀ1Þ Þ P dða rðjÞ ; b rðjÞ Þ; j ¼ 2; . . . ; n: ð4Þ
Remark 1. If k = 1, then the OWD measure is reduced to the OWAD operator (2).

However the OWAD and the OWD are mainly used to aggregate or measure the data taking the form of exact numerical, in what follows, we extend these ordered weighted distance measures to accommodate the situation in which the input data is provided with intuitionistic fuzzy numbers.
3. Intuitionistic fuzzy ordered weighted distance measure

div.head: Intuitionistic fuzzy sets
div.p: Intuitionistic fuzzy set (IFS) introduced by Atanassov [3] is an extension of the classical fuzzy set, which is a suitable way to deal with vagueness. Since its appearance, the IFS has been widely applied to the decision-making problems [4,6,8,18,[29][30][31][32]34,[36][37][38][41][42][43][44][45][46][47][48]51,54,61,62]. It can be defined as follows.
Definition 4. Let a set X = {x 1 , x 2 , . . . , x n } be fixed, an IFS A in X is given as following:
div.formula: A ¼ fhx; l A ðxÞ; v A ðxÞijx 2 Xg:ð5Þ
div.p: The numbers l A (x) and v A (x) represent, respectively, the membership degree and non-membership degree of the element x to the set A, for all x 2 X. The pair ðl A ðxÞ; v A ðxÞÞ is called an intuitionistic fuzzy number (IFN) and each IFN can be simply denoted as
div.formula: a = (l a , v a ), where l a 2 [0, 1], v a 2 [0, 1], l a + v a 6 1.
div.p: Additionally, S(a) = l a À v a and H(a) = l a + v a are called the score and accuracy degree of a, respectively.
For any three IFNs a
div.formula: ¼ ðl a ; v a Þ; a 1 ¼ ðl a 1 ; v a 1 Þ and a 2 ¼ ðl a 2 ; v a 2 Þ
div.p: , the following operational laws are valid [40,53]: (1)
div.formula: a 1 þ a 2 ¼ ðl a 1 þ l a 2 À l a 1 Á l a 2 ; v a 1 Á v a 2 Þ, (2) ka ¼ 1 À ð1 À l a Þ k ; v k a .
div.p: To compare any two IFNs a 1 and a 2 , Xu and Yager [53] introduced a simple method as below:
If S(a 1 ) < S(a 2 ), then a 1 < a 2 ;
If S(a 1 ) = S(a 2 ), the (1) If H(a 1 ) < H(a 2 ), then a 1 < a 2 ;
(2) If H(a 1 ) = H(a 2 ), then a 1 = a 2 .
In order to measure the deviation between any two IFNs [44,46] defined the following distance:
div.formula: a 1 ¼ ðl a 1 ; v a 1 Þ and a 2 ¼ ðl a 2 ; v a 2 Þ, Xu
Definition 5. Let a 1 ¼ ðl a 1 ; v a 1 Þ and a 2 ¼ ðl a 2 ; v a 2 Þ be two IFNs, then d IFD ða 1 ; a 2 Þ ¼ ja 1 À a 2 j ¼ 1 2 ðjl a 1 À l a 2 j þ jv a 1 À v a 2 jÞð6Þ
div.p: is called an intuitionistic fuzzy distance (IFD) between a 1 and a 2 .
The intuitionistic fuzzy distance is non-negativity, commutativity, reflexivity and triangle inequality. These properties can be demonstrated with the following theorem.
Theorem 1. For any three IFNs a = (l a , v a ), a 1 ¼ l a 1 ; v a 1 and
div.formula: a 2 ¼ ðl a 2 ; v a 2 Þ, then(1)
div.p: Non-negativity: d IFD (a 1 , a 2 ) P 0;
div.formula: Commutativity: d IFD (a 1 , a 2 ) = d IFD (a 2 , a 1 ); (3) Reflexivity: d IFD (a, a) = 0; (4) Triangle inequality: d IFD (a 1 , a) + d IFD (a, a 2 ) P d IFD (a 1 , a 2 ).
div.p: Proof. The proofs of property (1-3) can be found in Xu [46]. The proof of the property ( 4) is given as following. Since
div.formula: jl a 1 À l a 2 j ¼ jl a 1 À l a þ l a À l a 2 j 6 jl a 1 À l a j þ jl a À l a 2 j and jv a 1 À v a 2 j ¼ jv a 1 À v a þ v a À v a 2 j 6 jv a 1 À v a j þ jv a À v a 2 j:
div.p: Then we can get 1 2
div.formula: ðjl a 1 À l a 2 j þ jv a 1 À v a 2 jÞ 6 1 2 ðjl a 1 À l a j þ jv a 1 À v a jÞ þ 1 2 ðjl a À l a 2 j þ jv a À v a 2 jÞ: That is d IFD ða 1 ; a 2 Þ 6 d IFD ða 1 ; aÞ þ d IFD ða; a 2 Þ:
div.p: This completes the proof of Theorem 1. h

Distance and similarity measures of IFSs, as an important research topic in the IFS theory, have been investigated by many authors [9,[11][12][13]17,19,29,31,35,41,50,54]. However, it seems that in the literature there is no investigation on ordered weighted distance measures between IFSs, all the above suggested distance and similarity measures consider just an arithmetic average or weighted average for deviation between IFNs, and take the importance of each deviation value into consideration. Motivated by the idea of the OWD measure and the OWAD operator, next we shall develop an ordered weighted distance between IFSs, which can not only emphasize importance of ordered position of each deviation value, but also provide a parameterized family of distance aggregation operators between intuitionistic fuzzy sets.

div.head: Intuitionistic fuzzy ordered weighted distance (IFOWD) operator
div.p: Based on above information, let X be the set of all IFNs, e A ¼ ða 1 ; a 2 ; . . . ; a n Þ and e B ¼ ðb 1 ; b 2 ; . . . ; b n Þ be two sets of IFNs, then we can define an intuitionistic fuzzy weighted distance (IFWD) operator and intuitionistic fuzzy ordered weighted distance (IFOWD) operator as follows. Definition 6. An intuitionistic fuzzy weighted distance operator of dimension n is a mapping IFWD: X n Â X n ? R that has an associated weighting vector W = (w 1 , w 2 , . . . , w n ) with w j 2 [0, 1] and P n j¼1 w j ¼ 1, according to the following formula:
div.formula: IFWDð e A; e BÞ ¼ X n j¼1 w j ðd IFD ða j ; b j ÞÞ k ! 1=k ; k > 0ð7Þ
div.p: Xu and Chen [41] defined a different weighted distance between two intuitionistic fuzzy relations, and applied it to multiple attribute decision making. But using our defined intuitionistic fuzzy weighted distance will bring us the additional advantages in comparison between IFNs. This is the reason that we adopt the new intuitionistic fuzzy weighted distance measure in this paper.
Definition 7. An intuitionistic fuzzy ordered weighted distance operator of dimension n is a mapping IFOWD: X n Â X n ? R that has an associated weighting vector W = (w

The intuitionistic fuzzy ordered weighted distance (IFOWD) operator is an extension of the OWD measure and the OWAD operator for situations where the available information can not be assessed with exact numbers but it is possible to use intuitionistic fuzzy numbers. It uses the main characteristics of the OWD measure and the OWAD operator. The main advantage of this operator is that it can relieve (or intensify) the influence of unduly large or unduly small deviations on the aggregation results by assigning them low (or high) weights. An interesting issue is the determination of the weighting vectors associated with the ordered weighted distance measures. In the literature, we find a lot of methods for determining the OWA weights that can also be implemented for the IFOWD operator, such as Gaussian distribution based method [39], least squares based method [1,2], for more research on the methods for determining the OWA weights, see for example [5,7,10,[14][15][16]20,25,[56][57][58]. Inspired by Xu and Chen [49] and Xu and Xia [52], in the following, we give other three ways to determine the weighting vectors:
(1) Let
div.formula: w j ¼ d IFD
div.p: then w j P 0, j = 1,2,. . . , n, and
div.formula: P n j¼1 w j ¼ 1.
div.p: We find that the weight vector derived from Eq. ( 10) is a monotonic decreasing sequence, the weight vector derived from Eq. ( 11) is a monotonic increasing sequence, and the weight vector derived from Eq. ( 14) combine the above two cases, i.e., the closer the value d IFD (a r(j) ,b r(j) ) to the mean
div.formula: d IFD ða 1 ; b 1 Þ ¼ 1 2 ðj0:8 À 0:5j þ j0:2 À 0:1jÞ ¼ 0:2 Similarly, we have d IFD ða 2 ; b 2 Þ ¼ 0:05; d IFD ða 3 ; b 3 Þ ¼ 0:25; d IFD ða 4 ; b 4 Þ ¼ 0:1 Then d IFD ða rð1Þ ; b rð1Þ Þ ¼ d IFD ða 3 ; b 3 Þ ¼ 0:25
div.p: Similarly, we have d IFD ða rð2Þ ; b rð2Þ Þ ¼ 0:2; d IFD ða rð3Þ ; b rð3Þ Þ ¼ 0:1; d IFD ða rð4Þ ; b rð4Þ Þ ¼ 0:05

Then we can get the weighting vector W = (0.42, 0.33, 0.17, 0.08) if we use Eq. ( 10), and without loss of generality, suppose k = 2, if we calculate the distance between e A and e B using the IFOWD operator, we get the following:

div.head: IFOWDð e
div.p: A; e BÞ ¼ ð0:42 Â 0:

An interesting issue arises in the analysis of the IFOWD measure, namely, the ordered weighted similarity measures of IFSs. Note that 0 6 IFOWD 6 1, then the intuitionistic fuzzy ordered weighted similarity (IFOWS) measure is given by IFOWS = 1 À IFOWD. As we can see, the IFOWS is the dual of the IFOWD, so it can be studied in a similar way for all of the extensions mentioned in the rest of this paper.

The IFOWD operator is commutative, monotonic, bounded, idempotent, non-negative and reflexive but it does not accomplish always the triangle inequality. These properties can be proved with the following theorems: rðjÞ for all j, and then
div.formula: Theorem 2 (Commutativity -OWA aggregation). Assume f is the IFOWD operator, then f ðða 1 ; b 1 Þ; . . . ; ða n ; b n ÞÞ ¼ f a 0 1 ; b 0 1 À Á ; . . . ; a 0 n ; b 0 n À Á À Á
f ðða 1 ; b 1 Þ; . . . ; ða n ; b n ÞÞ ¼ f a 0 1 ; b 0 1 À Á ; . . . ; a 0 n ; b 0 n À Á À Á
div.p: This completes the proof of Theorem 2. h
Note that the commutativity of the IFOWD can also be studied from the context of a distance measure, which can be proved with the following theorem:
div.formula: Theorem 3 (Commutativity -distance measure). Assume f is the IFOWD operator, then f ðða 1 ; b 1 Þ; . . . ; ða n ; b n ÞÞ ¼ f ððb 1 ; a 1 Þ; . . . ;
! 1=k 6 X n j¼1 w j r k ! 1=k ¼ r k X n j¼1 w j ! 1=k ¼ r; f ðða 1 ; b 1 Þ; . . . ; ða n ; b n ÞÞ ¼ X n j¼1 w j d IFD ða rðjÞ ; b rðjÞ Þ k ! 1=k P X n j¼1 w j s k ! 1=k ¼ s k X n j¼1 w j ! 1=k ¼ s:
div.p: This completes the proof of Theorem 5. h Theorem 6 (Idempotency). Assume f is the IFOWD operator, if ja j À b j j = d for all j, then f ðða 1 ; b 1 Þ; . . . ; ða n ; b n ÞÞ ¼ d:
div.formula: Proof. Let f ðða 1 ; b 1 Þ; . . . ; ða n ; b n ÞÞ ¼ ð X n j¼1 w j d IFD ða rðjÞ ; b rðjÞ Þ k Þ 1=k : Because d IFD (a j , b j ) = d
Proof. Let f ða 1 ; a 1 Þ; . . . ; ða n ; a n Þ ð Þ ¼ X n j¼1 w j d IFD ða rðjÞ ; a rðjÞ Þ À Á k ! 1=k
div.p: Because d IFD (a j , a j ) = ja j À a j j = 0 for all j, then d IFD ða rðjÞ ; a rðjÞ Þ ¼ 0; j ¼ 1; 2; . . . ; n
This completes the proof of Theorem 8. h

div.head: Families of the IFOWD operators
div.p: By using a different manifestation in the weighting vector W and parameter k, we are able to obtain a wide range of particular types of the IFOWD operator. The selection of the particular case (or other cases found in the IFOWD) depends on the particular interest of the decision maker in the specific problem considered.

div.head: Analyzing the weighting vector W
div.p: By choosing a different manifestation of the weighting vector in the IFOWD operator, we are able to obtain different types of distance measures, such as intuitionistic fuzzy maximum distance, the intuitionistic fuzzy minimum distance, the intuitionistic fuzzy normalized distance (IFND), the intuitionistic fuzzy weighted distance (IFWD), the step-IFOWD, the window-IFOWD, the median-IFOWD, the olympic-IFOWD and the centered-IFOWD. Remark 2. For example, the intuitionistic fuzzy maximum distance, the intuitionistic fuzzy minimum distance, the step-IFOWD, the IFND and the IFWD are obtained as follows:

The intuitionistic fuzzy maximum distance is found if w 1 = 1 and w j = 0, for all j -1. The intuitionistic fuzzy minimum distance if w n = 1 and w j = 0, for all jn. More generally, if w k = 1 and w j = 0 for all jk, we get the step-IFOWD operator. The IFND is formed when w j = 1/n for all j. The IFWD is obtained when the ordered position of the d IF- D (a j , b j ) is the same as the ordered position of the d IFD (a r(j) , b r(j) ).

Remark 3. Another particular case is the olympic-IFOWD. This operator is found when w 1 = w n = 0 and for all others w j⁄ = 1/ (n À 2). Note that if n = 3 or n = 4, the olympic-IFOWD is transformed in the median-IFOWD. Remark 4. Note that it is possible to present a general form of the olympic-IFOWD operator, considering that w j =0 for j = 1,2,. . . , k, n, n À 1, . . . , n À k + 1; and for all others, w j⁄ = 1/(n À 2) where k < n/2. Note that if k = 1, then this general form becomes the usual olympic-IFOWD. If k = (n À 1)/2, then it becomes the median-IFOWD operator.

Remark 5. Additionally, it is also possible to present the contrary case of the general olympic-IFOWD operator. In this case, w j = (1/2k) for j = 1,2,. . ., k, n, n À 1, . . ., n À k + 1; and w j = 0, for all others, where k < n/2. Note that if k = 1, then we get the contrary case of the median-IFOWD. Remark 6. A further interesting family is the S-IFOWD operator. It can be subdivided in three classes: the ''orlike'', the ''andlike'' and the generalized S-IFOWD operators. The generalized S-IFOWD operator is obtained when

where a, b 2 [0, 1] and a + b 6 1. Note that if a = 0, the generalized S-IFOWD operator becomes the ''andlike'' S-IFOWD, and if b = 0, it becomes the ''orlike'' S-IFOWD. Note also that if a + b = 1, we get the intuitionistic fuzzy Hurwicz distance criteria.

Remark 7. Another family of aggregation operator that could be used is the centered-IFOWD operator. Following the same methodology than Yager [57], we could define an IFOWD operator as a centered aggregation operator if it is symmetric, strongly decaying and inclusive. It is symmetric if w j = w j+nÀ1 . It is strongly decaying when i < j 6 (n + 1)/2 then w i < w j and when i > j P (n + 1)/2 then w i < w j . It is inclusive if w j > 0. Note that it is possible to consider a softening of the second condition by using w i 6 w j instead of w i < w j . We shall refer to this as softly decaying centered-IFOWD operator. Another particular situation of the centered-IFOWD operator appears if we remove the third condition. We shall refer to it as a non-inclusive centered-IFOWD operator.
Remark 8. Using a similar methodology, we could develop numerous other families of IFOWD operators. For more information, refer to [21][22][23][24][25]49,52]

where (r(1), r(2),. . ., r(n)) is any permutation of (1, 2, . . ., n), such that (9) holds. Note that if w j = 1/n for all j, we get intuitionistic fuzzy normalized Hamming distance (IFNHD). The intuitionistic fuzzy weighted Hamming distance (IFWHD) is obtain if the ordered position of the d IFD (a j , b j ) is the same as the ordered position of the d IFD (a r(j) , b r(j) ).
Remark 10. If k = 2, the IFOWD operator is reduced to the intuitionistic fuzzy ordered weighted Euclidean distance (IFOWED) operator:
div.formula: IFOWEDð e A; e BÞ ¼ ffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffi X n j¼1 w j ðd IFD ða rðjÞ ; b rðjÞ ÞÞ 2 v u u t ;ð16Þ
div.p: where (r(1), r(2),. . ., r(n)) is any permutation of (1, 2, . . ., n), such that (9) holds. Note that if w j = 1/n for all j, we get intuitionistic fuzzy normalized Euclidean distance (IFNED). The intuitionistic fuzzy weighted Euclidean distance (IFWED) is obtain if the ordered position of the d IFD (a j , b j ) is the same as the ordered position of the d IFD (a r(j) , b r(j) ).
Remark 11. If k ? 0, then the IFOWD measure is reduced to the intuitionistic fuzzy ordered weighted geometric distance (IFOWGD):
div.formula: IFOWGDð e A; e BÞ ¼ Y n j¼1 ðd IFD ða rðjÞ ; b rðjÞ ÞÞ w j ;ð17Þ
div.p: where (r(1), r(2),. . ., r(n)) is any permutation of (1, 2, . . . , n), such that (9) holds. Note that if w j = 1/n for all j, we get intuitionistic fuzzy normalized geometric distance (IFNGD). The intuitionistic fuzzy weighted geometric distance (IFWGD) is obtain if the ordered position of the d IFD (a j , b j ) is the same as the ordered position of the d IFD (a r(j) , b r(j) ). Note that the IFOWGD can only be used sometimes when all the individual distances are different from 0. That is, when d IFD (a j , b j ) -0, for all j.

Remark 12. If one of e A or e B is reduced to (0, 0, . . . , 0), then we can get the generalized intuitionistic fuzzy ordered weighted averaging (GIFOWA) operator [62]. Then, we are able to obtain a wide range of particular types of the GIFOWA operator by using a different manifestation in the weighting vector W and parameter k, such as the generalized intuitionistic fuzzy weighted averaging (GIFWA) operator [62], the intuitionistic fuzzy ordered weighted averaging (IFOWA) operator [40], the intuitionistic fuzzy ordered weighted geometric (IFOWG) operator [53], the intuitionistic fuzzy weighted average (IFWA) operator [40], the intuitionistic fuzzy weighted geometric (IFWG) operator [53], the intuitionistic fuzzy maximum operator and the intuitionistic fuzzy minimum operator. For further research on the intuitionistic fuzzy aggregation operators, see for example [37,40,48,51,53].

div.head: Multiple attribute group decision-making with the IFOWD operator
div.p: In this paper, we consider a decision-making application in the selection of investments under uncertainty. Let A = {A 1 , A 2 , . . ., A m } be a discrete set of alternatives, and C = {C 1 , C 2 , . . ., C n } be the set of attributes (or characteristics). Let E = {e 1 , e 2 , . . . , e t } be the set of decision makers (whose weighting vector is V ¼ ðv 1 ; v 2 ; . . . ; v t Þ; v k P 0; P t k¼1 v k ¼ 1). Each decision maker provides his own payoff matrix x ðkÞ hi mÂn . Moreover, according to their objectives, the decision-makers establish a collective ideal investment for the company using fuzzy subsets as shown in Table 1, where I is the ideal strategy expressed by a fuzzy subset, C i is the ith characteristic to consider.
Then based on the IFOWD operator, we propose a method for group decision making under intuitionistic fuzzy environment, which involves the following steps:
Step 1: Use the IFWA operator [40] to aggregate the information of the decision makers E by using the weighting vector V. The result is the fuzzy collective payoff matrix (x hi ) mÂn , where
div.formula: x hi ¼ P t k¼1 v k x ðkÞ hi .
div.p: Step 2: Calculate the weighting vector W to be used in the aggregation. Note that W = (w 1 , w 2 , . . ., w n ) such that P n j¼1 w j ¼ 1 and w j 2 [0, 1].

Step 3: Calculate the distance between the ideal investment with the aggregated results by using the IFOWD operator. Note that it is possible to consider a wide range of IFOWD operators, such as those described in Sections 3 and 4.

Step 4: Adopt decisions according to the results found in the previous steps. Select the alternative/s that provides the best result/s. Moreover, establish an ordering or a ranking of the alternatives from the most to the least preferred alternative to enable consideration of more than one selection.

div.head: Illustrative example
div.p: In the following, we are going to develop a numerical example of the new approach. We analyze the results obtained by using different types of IFOWD operators and we see that depending on the aggregation operator used, the decision may be different. Note also that the IFOWD operator may be applied in similar problems as the OWD measure and the OWAD operator.
Assume a decision-maker wants to invest money in a company. After analyzing the market, he considers six possible alternatives:
(1) Invest in a chemical company called A 1 .
(2) Invest in a food company called A 2 .
(3) Invest in a computer company called A 3 . (4) Invest in a car company called A 4 .
(5) Invest in a furniture company called A 5 . (6) Invest in a pharmaceutical company called A 6 .

After careful review of the information, the group of experts establishes the following general information about the investments. They summarize the information of the investments in six general characteristics:
(1) C 1 : benefits in the short term;
(2) C 2 : benefits in the mid term;
div.formula: ij ¼ l x ij ; v x ij
div.p: , where l x ij denotes the degree of the alternative A i satisfies the situation C j ; v x ij denotes the degree does not satisfy the situation C j .
According to their objectives, the company establishes the following collective ideal investment shown in Table 5.

With this information, we can make an aggregation to make a decision. First, we aggregate the information of the three experts to obtain a unified payoff matrix. We use the IFWA [40] operator to obtain this matrix while assuming that V = (0.3, 0.3, 0.4). The results are shown in Table 6.

It is now possible to develop different methods based on the IFOWD operator for the selection of an investment. In this example, we consider the intuitionistic fuzzy maximum distance, the intuitionistic fuzzy minimum distance, the IFWHD, the IFWED, the IFOWHD operator, the IFOWED operator and the IFOWGD operator. For convenience, we assume the following weighting vector W = (0.09, 0.17, 0.24, 0.24, 0.17, 0.09), which is derived by the Gaussian distribution based method [39]. The results are shown in Table 7.

As we can see, for most of the cases the best alternative is A 2 because it seems to be the one with the lowest distance to the ideal investment. However, for some particular situations, we may find another optimal choice. Therefore, it is of interest to establish an ordering of the investments for each particular case. Note that the best choice is the one with the lowest distance. The results are shown in Table 8.

As we can see, depending on the distance aggregation operator used, the ordering of the strategies is different. Therefore, depending on the distance aggregation operator used, the results may lead to different decisions.

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: In this paper, we have suggested an intuitionistic fuzzy ordered weighted distance (IFOWD) operator, which is very useful to deal with the decision information represented in intuitionistic fuzzy numbers under uncertain situations. The main advantage of the IFOWD operator is that it can alleviate the influence of unduly large (or small) deviations on the aggregation results by assigning them low (or high) weights. Moreover, it provides a parameterized family of aggregation operators and distance measures. We have given three ways to determine the associated weighting vectors and studied some of its main properties and particular cases. With the relationship between distance measures and similarity measures, the corresponding ordered weighted similarity measures for IFSs has been obtained.

The IFOWD operator can be applied in a lot of situations already considered with the Hamming distance and Euclidean distance such as in statistics, economics and engineering, decision theory, soft computing and fuzzy set theory. In this paper, we have focused on an application in a group decision making problem regarding the selection of investments. We have seen that this approach provides better information for decision making because it is able to consider a wide range of scenarios depending on the interests of the decision-maker.

In future research, we expect to develop further extensions by adding new characteristics in the problem such as the use of inducing variables or probabilistic aggregations. Ordering of the strategies.
Ordering

div.head: Acnowledgments
div.p: The author is very grateful to the editor and the anonymous referees for their insightful and constructive comments and suggestions, which have been very helpful in improving the paper. This research was supported by Zhejiang Province Natural Science Foundation (Grant No. Y6110777).
